revision_history.draft:
After the downpour there was a gap
between my teeth. I swallowed and it
was still there — that crescent of absence,
the thing I'd carried all week inside my mouth.

I stood under the awning of a pharmacy
and the rain did not fall on me.
It sat on the brim of someone else's hat,
on the plastic bag slung across their chest,
and I could hear its small percussion
through the bones of my skull, behind
my closed eyelids. Somewhere a siren
went up a pitch, then down.

The shelves held everything except the name
of what I'd come for — glycerin, perhaps,
or the word for glycerin in another language.
My fingers traced the grooves between products
the way water finds the fractures in rock,
following the soft lines until the surface
becomes something else. A kind of skin.

There was a woman at the counter with two children.
The boys pressed their faces into her shoulders
and she held them open like a book
someone has turned to the wrong page of —
the one where rain seeps through the binding,
where the margin clouds and the text
becomes someone else's writing, legible
for only a few more readings.

I tasted iron. I tasted the inside
of a gate somewhere, rust collected
in the teeth of someone who'd left them
open all summer while rain did its work —
not destruction but the opposite:
how a surface can remember every atom
it ever lost. The woman at the counter
said something to the boys. They didn't answer.
She said it again and the word sat
on top of the first one like water
finding the exact shape of a stone.

Underneath my tongue, where salt dissolves,
there was a phrase I couldn't retrieve —
a name, a town, the color of a jacket
I'd worn so long ago that rain had made it
part of me, or something before me.
The awning offered no protection from this.
The awning was just fabric stretched across metal
and the wind could tear it down at any time.

After a while I walked back onto the sidewalk.
Every surface had gone grainy — wet
concrete, wet air, the sound of a bus
slowing at the stop I wasn't using.
I could hear my own breathing
as if from outside a different body,
and somewhere a dog barked once,
cleanly, like a word you'd forgotten
the meaning of just after saying it.

The rain didn't change anything permanent.
That's what I wanted to tell myself — the gap
between my teeth would fill. The name
would return. The iron taste
would become something else or disappear.
But under an awning with no one else inside,
I held my hands apart and the palms
were wet with nothing I was keeping from.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The central conceit — rain as a force that erodes memory through physical, embodied experience — is genuinely strong and earns its weight. The passage beginning "I tasted iron" has real momentum: the shift from external landscape to bodily sensation to geological metaphor (water in rock) to the final image of wet palms with nothing kept inside. That ending does genuine work.

The siren passage ("went up a pitch, then down") is concise and earns its place — it's one sound selected for texture rather than atmosphere.

"Like water / finding the exact shape of a stone" — this line has compression that rewards close reading. The image does specific physical labor without explanation.

The closing image (hands held apart with wet palms) is quiet, earned by what came before, and trusts the reader to feel emptiness without naming it.

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Cliché intrusion — "line 16"**
> My fingers traced the grooves between products / the way water finds the fractures in rock,
>
> **Direction:** The geological metaphor here is doing what the siren and the dog bark later do: explaining itself through abstraction. Cut or replace with a concrete, sensory gesture. What does the hand actually *do*? Trace? Map? The verb "traced" already implies pattern — find a verb that resists meaning before it arrives.

**Abstraction bloat — lines 14–20**
> Somewhere a siren went up a pitch, then down.
>
> The shelves held everything except the name
> of what I'd come for — glycerin, perhaps,
> or the word for glycerin in another language.
>
> My fingers traced the grooves between products
> the way water finds the fractures in rock,
> following the soft lines until the surface
> becomes something else. A kind of skin.
>
> There was a woman at the counter with two children.
> The boys pressed their faces into her shoulders
> and she held them open like a book
> someone has turned to the wrong page of —
> the one where rain seeps through the binding,
> where the margin clouds and the text
> becomes someone else's writing, legible
> for only a few more readings.
>
> **Direction:** The siren line is fine. Lines 15–20 are three separate images stacked as one — the shelves, the fingers tracing, the woman with children. Choose *one*. Each of those gestures toward abstraction (the missing name, the foreign word for glycerin, the metaphorical book) and the poem loses specificity at exactly the moment it should be most grounded. The finger tracing water-in-rock passage is already doing the geological work — cut or collapse.

**Sentimentality — lines 29–31**
> I could hear my own breathing
> as

revision_history.draft:
After the downpour there was a gap
between my teeth. I swallowed and it
was still there — that crescent of absence,
the thing I'd carried all week inside my mouth.

I stood under the awning of a pharmacy
and the rain did not fall on me.
It sat on the brim of someone else's hat,
on the plastic bag slung across their chest,
and I could hear its small percussion
through the bones of my skull, behind
my closed eyelids. Somewhere a siren
went up a pitch, then down.

The shelves held rubbing alcohol, bandages,
a pack of cigarettes someone had left.
My fingers traced the spaces between products —
not map but grooves, each one a question
I'd pressed into rock and kept pressing,
following the soft lines until the surface
became something I could hold inside my hand.

There was a woman at the counter with two children.
The boys pressed their faces into her shoulders
and she held them open like a book
she'd turned to the wrong page of —
the one where wetness seeped through,
where the paper thinned and clouded,
and you could read what came before
in the margins, someone else's script,
legible for only a few more readings.

I tasted iron. I tasted the gate
somewhere I'd left open all summer —
not destruction but how a surface
can remember every atom it ever lost.
The woman at the counter said something to the boys.
They didn't answer. She said it again.
The word sat on top of the first one
like water finding the exact shape of a stone.

Under my tongue, where salt dissolves,
there was a phrase I couldn't retrieve —
a name, a town, the color of a jacket
I'd worn so long ago that rain had made it
part of me or something before me.
The awning offered no protection from this.
The awning was just fabric stretched across metal
and the wind could tear it down at any time.

After a while I walked back onto the sidewalk.
Every surface had gone grainy — wet
concrete, wet air, the sound of a bus
slowing at the stop I wasn't using.
I heard my own breathing
from outside a different body,
and somewhere a dog barked once,
cleanly, like a word you'd forgotten
the meaning of just after saying it.

The rain didn't change anything permanent.
That's what I wanted to tell myself — the gap
between my teeth would fill. The name
would return. The iron taste
would become something else or disappear.
But under an awning with no one else inside,
I held my hands apart and the palms
were wet with nothing I was keeping from.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The closing image — "I held my hands apart and the palms / were wet with nothing I was keeping from" — is the poem's strongest moment. It trusts silence and physical sensation entirely, and it earns its weight because everything before it has been specific enough to support it.

The siren line ("went up a pitch, then down") works in isolation because it's one sound selected for texture rather than atmosphere.

"Like water / finding the exact shape of a stone" — this is genuinely compressed. The image does physical work without explanation.

**Lines 19–20:** "the word sat on top of the first one like water / finding the exact shape of a stone" — the final line here earns its abstraction because it's grounded in a concrete, repeated gesture (water finding a stone's shape). This is where the poem trusts metaphor to do heavy lifting.

The dog barking once near the end has real sonic economy. It arrives late enough that it sounds like pure noise.

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Abstraction and stacked imagery — lines 15–20 (near revision note)**
> My fingers traced the grooves between products / the way water finds the fractures in rock,
> following the soft lines until the surface
> becomes something else. A kind of skin.
>
> There was a woman at the counter with two children.
> The boys pressed their faces into her shoulders
> and she held them open like a book
> someone has turned to the wrong page of —
> the one where rain seeps through the binding,
> where the margin clouds and the text
> becomes someone else's writing, legible
> for only a few more readings.

*Three images in three lines.* The poem is doing the opposite of what it claims: instead of erasing details, it accumulates them. **Direction:** Choose one image or remove all three. The fingers tracing water-in-rock passage is already doing geological work — cut or collapse to find the single gesture that most closely resembles how memory actually *feels* under rain's pressure.

**Redundancy / retelling — lines 27–31**
> I tasted iron.
> I tasted the inside
> of a gate somewhere, rust collected
> in the teeth of someone who'd left them
> open all summer while rain did its work —
> not destruction but the opposite:
> how a surface can remember every atom
> it ever lost.

This passage restates what was already said more concretely earlier. **Direction:** Cut or compress. The dog-bark ending is closer in quality and brevity, so the poem should move toward that model: one image per sentence, no explanation, no accumulation of abstract meaning.

**"The gap between my teeth" — line 1**
> After the downpour there was a gap

After the downpour there was a gap
between my teeth. I swallowed and it
was still there — that crescent of absence,
the thing I'd carried all week inside my mouth.

I stood under the awning of a pharmacy
and the rain did not fall on me.
It sat on the brim of someone else's hat,
on the plastic bag slung across their chest,
and I could hear its small percussion
through the bones of my skull, behind
my closed eyelids. Somewhere a siren
went up a pitch, then down.

The shelves held rubbing alcohol, bandages,
a pack of cigarettes someone had left.
My fingers traced the spaces between products —
not map but grooves, each one a question
I'd pressed into rock and kept pressing,
following the soft lines until the surface
became something I could hold inside my hand.

There was a woman at the counter with two children.
The boys pressed their faces into her shoulders
and she held them open like a book
she'd turned to the wrong page of —
the one where wetness seeped through,
where the paper thinned and clouded,
and you could read what came before
in the margins, someone else's script,
legible for only a few more readings.

I tasted iron. I tasted the gate
somewhere I'd left open all summer —
not destruction but how a surface
can remember every atom it ever lost.
The woman at the counter said something to the boys.
They didn't answer. She said it again.
The word sat on top of the first one
like water finding the exact shape of a stone.

Under my tongue, where salt dissolves,
there was a phrase I couldn't retrieve —
a name, a town, the color of a jacket
I'd worn so long ago that rain had made it
part of me or something before me.
The awning offered no protection from this.
The awning was just fabric stretched across metal
and the wind could tear it down at any time.

After a while I walked back onto the sidewalk.
Every surface had gone grainy — wet
concrete, wet air, the sound of a bus
slowing at the stop I wasn't using.
I heard my own breathing
from outside a different body,
and somewhere a dog barked once,

cleanly,
like a word you'd forgotten
the meaning of just after saying it.

The rain didn't change anything permanent.
revision_history.critique:
## Workshop Response

### 1. What's Alive

The closing image — "I held my hands apart and the palms / were wet with nothing I was keeping from" — is the poem's strongest moment. It trusts silence and physical sensation entirely, and it earns its weight because everything before it has been specific enough to support it.

The dog barking once near the end ("somewhere a dog barked once, / cleanly") works in isolation: that single word arrives with real sonic economy at the right point — late enough to sound like pure noise, not commentary. It's doing what the poem is about (listening through rain).

"Like water / finding the exact shape of a stone" — this is genuinely compressed. The image does physical work without explanation.

**Lines 19–20:** "the word sat on top of the first one like water / finding the exact shape of a stone" — the final line here earns its abstraction because it's grounded in a repeated, concrete gesture (water finding a stone's shape). This is where the poem trusts metaphor to do heavy lifting.

### 2. What Isn't Working

**Redundancy and retelling — lines 15–20**
The passage accumulates images without sharpening: "fingers traced grooves between products" → "water finds fractures in rock" → "following the soft lines until the surface becomes something else." The three gestures are doing essentially the same work. **Direction:** Choose one or collapse to a single, more precise gesture that doesn't explain itself.

**Abstraction without grounding — lines 27–31**
The iron taste passage restates what was already said more concretely earlier: "the gate / somewhere I'd left open all summer." The poem is explaining its own metaphor rather than trusting it. **Direction:** Cut or compress to one line maximum, then move on.

**Cliché — "wet air" (line 34)**
This is filler language that could appear in any rain poem. It doesn't earn the reader's attention. **Direction:** Replace with a sensory detail specific only *this* scene has.

**Sentimentality — "I heard my own breathing / from outside a different body" (lines 31–2)**
The self-as-external-object trick is doing emotional work it doesn't need to do, and the line break after "different body" creates slack where tension lives. **Direction:** Either sharpen this moment with a concrete sensory detail that *makes* the strangeness felt, or cut — because right now it's telling the reader about altered consciousness rather than rendering it.

**Weak transition — "The rain didn't change anything permanent." (line 36)**
This is the poem's thesis statement. It summarizes what the images should have been doing. **Direction:** Remove entirely. The closing dog barking and the wet palms are already doing this work more effectively

revision_history.draft:
After the downpour there was a gap
between my teeth. I swallowed and it
was still there — that crescent, the thing
I'd carried all week inside my mouth.

Under an awning pharmacy, rain
on someone else's hat, on plastic bags.
Siren up then down. Shelves held
rubbing alcohol, bandages, a pack
of cigarettes I could not bear to touch.

A woman at the counter with two boys.
They pressed their faces into her shoulders,
she held them open like a book
turned to the wrong page — that thinning,
that clouding, where you read what came before
in someone else's script, almost legible,

tongue tasted iron, gate I'd left all summer,
not destruction but how surface remembers
every atom it ever lost. Under my tongue,
where salt dissolves, a phrase I couldn't retrieve —
a name, a town, the color of a jacket
I wore until rain made it part of me.

Fabric stretched across metal offered no protection.
Wind could tear it down at any time.

After a while I walked back onto wet concrete,
wet sidewalk, slowing bus, one barking dog

cleanly,
like a word you'd forgotten
the meaning of just after saying it.

My hands had gone grainy — not holding anything.

final_poem:
After the downpour there was a gap
between my teeth. I swallowed and it
was still there — that crescent, the thing
I'd carried all week inside my mouth.

Under an awning pharmacy, rain
on someone else's hat, on plastic bags.
Siren up then down. Shelves held
rubbing alcohol, bandages, a pack
of cigarettes I could not bear to touch.

A woman at the counter with two boys.
They pressed their faces into her shoulders,
she held them open like a book
turned to the wrong page — that thinning,
that clouding, where you read what came before
in someone else's script, almost legible,

tongue tasted iron, gate I'd left all summer,
not destruction but how surface remembers
every atom it ever lost. Under my tongue,
where salt dissolves, a phrase I couldn't retrieve —
a name, a town, the color of a jacket
I wore until rain made it part of me.

Fabric stretched across metal offered no protection.
Wind could tear it down at any time.

After a while I walked back onto wet concrete,
wet sidewalk, slowing bus, one barking dog

cleanly,
like a word you'd forgotten
the meaning of just after saying it.

My hands had gone grainy — not holding anything.
